topic.title: Welcome to new ZeroTalk forum!
topic.body:
Supporting ZeroID account and site cloning. The old messages can be found at:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/1TaLk3zM7ZRskJvrh3ZNCDVGXvkJusPKQ

Other changes:
 - Massively cleaned up source code
 - The used size counter moved to comment textarea to make it more clear what it displays.
 - Aligned to center
 - Many other changes to make it work better and smoother

Username is unique / zeroid provider. So no other "red" user in sites that accepts ZeroID certificates, but every site can choose which ID certificate provider it accepts.

> [red](#comment_2_1PhuTzPYR1nigsp2JQESVrTPTNYUZ26ccB): That is pretty nice. Also, is the entire program self-contained within the initial extracted folder i.e. if I want to copy all my data and keep identities etc. is that the only folder I need to copy?

> [klauszimmermann](#comment_1_15QGRquMETTn5LnCHjTm1qa9eaXGtq7gpT): Let me say this: Zeroid.bit is broken. One cannot feasibly authenticate there. Firefox on Linux here and CPUs go up to 100% and the GUI looks like it froze. Actually what happens is that there's a lot of computation going on, but it works (although slow as hell). 

Probably your browser does not support webgl properly, so it falls back to software rendering. Can you please check your value of "Major Performance Caveat" on https://www.browserleaks.com/webgl page?

Edit: Added performance monitoring to ZeroID and disabling the animation if necessary

> [klauszimmermann](#comment_2_15QGRquMETTn5LnCHjTm1qa9eaXGtq7gpT): Sure, I see why now, but the question is: why force the use of WebGL for the creation of a certificate?

It's not forced, it should fall back to non-webgl solution if its not supported by the browser, but the problem is your browser says it's supported, but in the reality its not in any useful form. But I think fixed this problem yesterday by monitoring performance and removing the animation if necessary. (checks the FPS in every 3 second and if under 25 then stops the animation)

ZeroNet is made for P2P dynamic content, so its heavily relies on javascript to make backend servers unnecessary.

> [user0](#comment_1_1NNqE1siwCEcXN9fYu9sEq9MVGmvqitVos): How to create your own site on ZeroNet?

You can have your own ZeroBlog or ZeroTalk by by pressing the ☰ icon on ZeroHello then choose Clone.

> [brunoloff](#comment_1_1KdQMFyXwPY2vjMDL9UiPnckwGbyvUjpcj): How does one clone by hand? (would also help me learn some of the internals)

- Create a new site: `zeronet.py siteCreate`
- Copy everything from data/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT to data/yoursiteaddress
- Delete **data/yoursiteaddress/data** directory and rename **data/yoursiteaddress/data-default** to **data/yoursiteaddress/data** to get a clean, empty site.
- Rename **data/users/content-default.json** to **data/users/content.json**
- Sign your site data files: `zeronet.py siteSign yoursiteaddress`
- Sign your site user content permissions: `zeronet.py siteSign yoursiteaddress --inner_path data/users/content.json`

2_16cnC4CxZKjMJNNopuiFQ9nVNiCk5mZ9CP.body:
> [s466531257boss](#comment_4_16cnC4CxZKjMJNNopuiFQ9nVNiCk5mZ9CP): PROBLEM
> : When used in FireFox ( Version 39.0 // Windows NT 6.3.1 x86-32 )after commenting, the textarea of the commentbox for a fresh comment is holding the size of the comment sent before .

> [s466531257boss](#comment_5_16cnC4CxZKjMJNNopuiFQ9nVNiCk5mZ9CP): ERROR
> : When used in Firefox ( Version 39.0 // Windows NT 6.3.1 x86-32 ) the site-specific request for interaction is not functioning though given as an option .

It's not really a bug: by default every time you new visit a site ZeroNet generates a new public address for you, that identifies you. The site has possibility to give permissions for that address or accept users registered on different site (ZeroID)

So it's like changing identites: You use the identity generated for this site or you use your identity generated for other site.

> [blob](#comment_1_14aVLodevcKrUDeLa8HArCJsi9MuUNf8Uu): Hello, whats about Anonimity and Security of ZeroNet websites?

You can [hide your IP address using Tor network](http://zeronet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/faq/#how-to-use-zeronet-with-tor) to get anonymity.

> [blob](#comment_2_14aVLodevcKrUDeLa8HArCJsi9MuUNf8Uu): i mean without Tor, anonymous websites.Its cool to use tor, but it was better if ZeroNet supports with own anonymous technique  by default to protect.

An anonymity network only works good if it has many peers on reliable, fast connection, so I think it would be a bad idea to start building our own network.

But as ZeroNet [privacy will increase](http://zeronet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/faq/#is-zeronet-anonymous) as it gather more peers.

> [blob](#comment_3_14aVLodevcKrUDeLa8HArCJsi9MuUNf8Uu): that means there is no priority to make websites more secure? to not allow to get be sniffed by third party companies?

More Tor features (hidden service) and/or i2p support is planned. SSL encryption added some weeks ago, so sniffing is no longer possible.
I'm not sure what you mean "more secure".

> [blob](#comment_4_14aVLodevcKrUDeLa8HArCJsi9MuUNf8Uu): i mean, i read not sure its right, this here:"A peer holds the entire site in a local directory. If this contains malicious or illegal content it can be accidentally run or viewed. Or it could be picked up in automated scans and the user held responsible."

It can be possible to create a "filter" for the hosted content, but i'm not sure if its a good idea to have a built-in censorship tool.

You only need to backup `data/users.json` to keep your identity.

2_1MS7WkWAZUSohgV5uUF2Ze3kdbifi4J82L.body:
Maelstrom was the main inspiration for creating ZeroNet.
I have already thought about a system like ZeroNet since mid-2014, but didn't had courage to start it (and lack of cryptography skills)
In December I was happy to see BitTorrent was working on similar system, downloaded it, but I was disappointed: It was closed source, Browser pinned and lack of dynamic content support. 
After that, I started to coding and 1 month later released ZeroNet's first working version.

> [nippletwister](#comment_35_1PvAyLAB5H1JKbiFjx95ZJXrNJVyWxs5Hf): It is not mine. It works with errors and I don't have any idea why.

ZeroNet sites loaded in sandboxed iframe, which is restrict some JavaScript functions eg. localStorage that is used by the flowershop demo. This is necessary, because you access all sites under the same domain (127.0.0.1 normally), so without it any site would able to access/modify other site's data. Local storage is accessible using the ZeroFrame API, so it required to modify the site's source code to make it work.

> [petko](#comment_2_1N4gn1fTkSb7DmjvxiXDVHVx9REgJZk2CR): Could you point out how will big files be hosted?

My idea: Site would able to define optional files which is not downloaded automatically. These files would end in a cache folder which has user-defined maxmum size, if this limit reached the best seeded file would be deleted automatically.

> [petko](#comment_4_1N4gn1fTkSb7DmjvxiXDVHVx9REgJZk2CR): OK, this is going to work for huge static sites, but not sure about sites with users-generated content:
> 
> If the site defines the optional files, the users will not be able to upload stuff - am I correct?

It would be possible to include optional files in user's content.json files, but the uploaded files this way would not be auto-downloaded by everyone only if they request it (eg. viewing the image from browser).
The initial distribution could be problematic this way (after the upload you have to wait until some ppl want to see it), but to avoid this there could be "super peers" on high speed connection who is automatically downloads every new file and keeps it until the distribution is guaranteed. 
My other idea to solve the initial seed problem: you would be able to friend or subscribe users and if he/she uploads a new file your client automatically downloads it and helping the distribution this way.

> Things that are downloaded are not always worthy to be stored. My understanding is that seeders should be able to decide whether to keep something or delete it. I.e. instead of "Like" button there will be "Seed" button :)

This is a good idea, the API could provide commands to "pin files" (does not get deleted) or instant deletion.
I have did more thinking about this and summarized my ideas problems/solutions here: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/163

1_12cS4bEGm4qMeAmUfrxZiRtMwNsv9QdsEo.body:
The database is acts as a cache of the json files to make the data query faster and easier. 
Every user has his/her own .json file that is only owner able to sign, so you can't distribute the database directly. To write to the database you have to modify your own .json file, sign it using your private key and publish it to other peers. They verify the signature and if its correct they update your database records according to the new .json file.

Editing your .json file will only effects your own entries (topics, comments, upvotes, etc.). 

There is a [dbschema.json](dbschema.json) file that defines how to do the json -> database entries conversion, so you can't just put/edit anything in the database. If you add a new entry it will be linked to your profile and it only allows you to edit/delete your own records.

3_1QH84f44yLPvMjMua9s7iM7c4RoJNZ2nTp.body:
> [oracle](#comment_45_1ED3Ho3kmzaKiECtyuqSjDpoE47rKuXeP): I don't know why old was added to the end of it but I removed the old and ZeroNet works again. I'm also on Linux.

When the user.json file saved (to avoid data lost at all costs) it's done this way:
 - New content written to user.json-new
 - Current users.json renamed to users.json-old
 - user.json-new renamed to users.json
 - users.json-old removed

So if you see users.json-old file it means for some reason the saving process is interrupted. I was unable to reproduce the problem, but I will keep my eye over it.

1_1NibKcCcidCHue94Rhr7F4Gvu3Lg6FAESp.body:
Hello,

It uses AES256 for encryption of messages and ECIES (same ECC curve as Bitcoin) for publickey based AES key exchange.

ZeroNet provides the API function that allows the P2P data sync and the cryptography functions. It is written in Python and the cryptography functions are in C++ (OpenSSL). The ZeroMail site is written in javascript (coffeescript): https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroMail

> [darkalama](#comment_2_1NibKcCcidCHue94Rhr7F4Gvu3Lg6FAESp): Please add in future versions PGP support.

Every data file is signed by the user's private key, so signing again with PGP is not necessary and would add significant overhead to the messages.

> [dividedby0](#comment_24_16iYwD5U2fNoS22p6447J7992iL3DHjSHY): Thanks, I didn't know I could click on the error. Is this something new with version 0.3.6 (r889)? What was the reasoning for having to make the changes to torrc?

Full tor support added in version 0.3.5, it include .onion addresses, so Tor peers able to communicate between each other without exit node (faster and more secure). This feature requires access to Tor control protocol to create new hidden services.

It's also possible to use without modifying torrc (like before 0.3.5) by running it `zeronet.py --tor disable --proxy 127.0.0.1:9050 --disable_udp`, but then you will loose ability to talk with other .onion addresses.

That message is displayed when the ipv4 port is intentionally closed. (Using a proxy or --tor always)

WebRTC is created for small networks video conference and the browsers has too much limitation: max connections per tab, storage limit, no sql, slow cryptography, you have to keep the tab open, security problems, it would also make full tor support impossible etc. 
You can already use ZeroNet without downloading anything by using an openproxy, but creating a light WebRTC client could be possible later if the technology (eg serviceworkers) becomes more mature.

> [blabla](#comment_4_1CuQ21M7tmpoeyG4HrW4ax1Pz4w3JvXuA5): even if it would be not as secure it still would open zeronet to a far more reach

It's already possible to reach the network without installing anything, eg.: http://bit.no.com:43110/talk.zeronetwork.bit/?Topic:2_1CuQ21M7tmpoeyG4HrW4ax1Pz4w3JvXuA5/WebRTC

The problem is it would not be less secure, but a security disaster: any site would able to stole your private key, so able to modify/delete your sites or content.

> [blabla](#comment_5_1CuQ21M7tmpoeyG4HrW4ax1Pz4w3JvXuA5): is it also selfupdating?

It's a normal ZeroNet client exposed to public, the user experience is identical to a downloaded + locally ran one.

1_1LgoHzNGWeijeZbJ8a1YgGjMCnjaM4BWG.body:
There is no content expiry (yet). You have two options to delete old content:
 - Implement to site code: When user submits new content delete contents older than X days
 - Create a script that checks loops through all user's data.json and modifies if necessary then signs/publish the modified files using site owner's privatekey.

> [anon](#comment_1_1LgoHzNGWeijeZbJ8a1YgGjMCnjaM4BWG): Is it planned to be implemented?

It's not possible, because you can't change any file without the user or the site owner signature.

> Is it possible to reject old content by other users instead of deleting your own (which is not guaranteed to happen)?

If you work with multiple files (eg. separate file for every image) then its possible to define them as optional files which is only downloaded if you display it on the website (see the ReactionGIFs site). So the old files will not be downloaded without any user interaction.

> [anon](#comment_2_1LgoHzNGWeijeZbJ8a1YgGjMCnjaM4BWG): Can i do the same thing for e.g textual content (without an index it doesn't seem possible)? 

It should also work with json files, but it's not really ideal for your usecase. I think it would be hard to run out of 10MB space if you add "keep only last x month of messages on save" solution. (this site is around 1MB after 300 topics without any deletion)

2_1NibKcCcidCHue94Rhr7F4Gvu3Lg6FAESp.body: SQLite does not support this, so the best way to do this is using disk encryption.

> [ow](#comment_4_13KqD3BoaRMudEG5QU2fnGLkSVx8qDXKof): If ZeroNet allows a peer to run both Tor hidden service and I2P hidden service at the same time (or go back and forth when they start it) those peers can still exchange info with other peers however, so it wouldn't be an isolated ZeroNet.

MITM is not a problem in ZeroNet, since there is no trusted peer, every data is signed by it's owner. Bundle I2P with ZeroNet (like the Tor client) would be harder, because of Java.

11_1PvAyLAB5H1JKbiFjx95ZJXrNJVyWxs5Hf.body: It could be possible to develop a Git plugin, that create a commit on every modification, so you would be able to follow source code changes and also gives you the ability to reverse things.

> [ow](#comment_24_13KqD3BoaRMudEG5QU2fnGLkSVx8qDXKof): You would still need to prevent the master private key from being lost, but it at least this allows for a method to manage security in layers. For example, you could keep your master private key on an air-gaped machine at all points in the process.

ZeroNet has similar implemented (not used by any site yet, so probably needs more testing): http://zeronet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/site_development/content_json/#signers_sign

So you would be able to create a signers_sign of `1:PUBLICADDRESS1,PUBLICADDRESS2,PUBLICADDRESS3` it would mean you can sign the site any of these public addresses. If you modify the starting `1` to `2` it would mean you need to sign the modifications with at least two of these keys. (eg 2 different machine, so if any of them hacked you still safe)

You can also set it by per-directory (using include), so it's possible to give moderation rights to someone without the ability to modify the site source code or add more than one people (public address) and request every moderation to be signed by atleast 2 moderators.

Other possibility to improve privatekey security: https://www.buytrezor.com/

> [zozon](#comment_80_1QBLGLcgKfcpfLmiDYuDzUKVXFfmTAew55): it would be nice to have something to KICK underlying zeronet.py into peer propagation, noticed that it is very inert in contacting peers around. 

When creating site:
 - Have opened port: Best case, anyone able to contact you immediately
 - Don't have opened port, but Tor is running fine (Tor: OK or ALWAYS in ZeroHello): The peers, who also have Tor running able to contact you immediately (after 1-2 minute of .onion address warmup), others have to wait 1-10 minutes if they have opened port, otherwise they not able to contact you.
 - Don't have opened port and Tor mode is not running (Tor: Error in ZeroHello): Only peers with opened port able to contact you and they are have to wait 1-10 minutes.

> [gomzik](#comment_42_1F6BMqittjWUStzUbRXm2kG2GQ3RdBLqFQ): See in my log while sign command run
> Site:1CpGZy..bEzd - [SKIPPED] data/users/content.json

If you get that message it means you signed the wrong file. By default it sign the root content.json, if you want to sign other content.json you need this: `zeronet.py siteSign yoursiteaddress --inner_path data/users/content.json`

If you sign the file using the command line then you may need to restart your client to get the changes. If you sign it using the sidebar then it's reload the new file, so no restart needed.

The point of blockchain is one thing: create a database that does not allow to modify earlier records.

This makes much sense in payment technology, but it's not optimal (and does not provide real benefit) to store web data.

> [antiphase](#comment_15_1NoRNknY1JbJ8nMdn88LwczyMDFnR1GtNw): Weird. That was happening with a different post yesterday.

The poster computer's time is out of sync. There is no central server in ZeroNet, so nobody can tell whats the time really is.

1_1PtoWgfjhzMK8qz1eTVG3QsawNQ4DL8c8Y.body:
> [ekaterina](#comment_85_1Mk5sVKeCrwMc3wSD11jM7DZTiqF5D9BaD): It makes use of both ECIES (Elliptic Curve Integrated Encryption Scheme) and AES encryption, I believe one is used for sharing the public key to use and the other for actually encrypting the mail, not sure why two different systems are used here, I'm not that experienced with cryptography.

Thanks for the reply, your observations are correct :)

It could be possible to use only ECIES (and it would be much simpler), but decided to use ECIES for secret sharing AES for messages, because it uses ~200byte less space/message this way and decrypting AES is around 100x faster than ECIES. More info: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/216

> [ekaterina](#comment_86_1Mk5sVKeCrwMc3wSD11jM7DZTiqF5D9BaD): Ah good to know, thanks for the link! For my site ECIES seems fast enough on my netbook, feels instant. But it's a lot less involved than ZeroMail :)

Yes, it's very fast: 100x ECC + AES = 0.7sec, 100x AES = 0.006sec on my old Core2Duo running on 32bit dlls, but every time you start ZeroMail it downloads all missed key exchanges since your last visit and try to decode it using ECIES, then download all new messages from users you have already have shared secret and decode it using AES. So it's only matter if you do batch 1000+ decodes.

> [balancer73](#comment_21_1PniNzyi8fygvwyBaLpA9oBDVWZ5fXuJUw): Strange effect. On external ZeroNet nodes my updating appears immediately. On the directly updated node — not :)

It's because you local client does not  get notified on file system changes, but the remote client exactly knows when and what changed, so it can update the database. The `--publish` [sends](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/blob/master/src/main.py#L362) a `siteReload` command to the local client if it's already running.

```
    def need(self, address, all_file=True):
        from Site import Site
        site = self.get(address)
        if not site:  # Site not exist yet
            return False
            # Try to find site with differect case
            ...
```

> [flappyearz](#comment_22_1QEfmMwKVxgR4rkREbdJYjgUmF3Zy8pwHt): Yeah, and is there a compulsory time sync? What about fake clocks? Clock in the far future?

Clients only accept content.json timestamped local time + 1 day in the future. So in worst case you will be locked out for 1 day.

> [flappyearz](#comment_23_1QEfmMwKVxgR4rkREbdJYjgUmF3Zy8pwHt): Sounds good, so I only have to write a script to timestamp T+23h any site I want to do a DoS? [...]

If you have the private key for the site's address  then yes, you can block updates. (but in that case the site is already fucked up, since you can delete it)
The user files are time stamped separately, so you can't cause any problem by that.

> [flappyearz](#comment_26_1QEfmMwKVxgR4rkREbdJYjgUmF3Zy8pwHt): Only myself?

Yes, every user has his/her own file and only able to update that one. For example yours: [data/users/1QEfmMwKVxgR4rkREbdJYjgUmF3Zy8pwHt/data.json](data/users/1QEfmMwKVxgR4rkREbdJYjgUmF3Zy8pwHt/data.json) and [data/users/1QEfmMwKVxgR4rkREbdJYjgUmF3Zy8pwHt/content.json](data/users/1QEfmMwKVxgR4rkREbdJYjgUmF3Zy8pwHt/content.json)
ZeroNet only synchronize these json files between the peers then the sql database is generated automatically by the application based on these files.

6_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh.body:
> [basxto](#comment_47_1PVcdu7USZH2kHMETbqDYLPjJZKCDWM52k): Yes, those with udp:// and http:// look like regular bittorent trackers. I know coppersurfer.tk and leechers-paradies.org.
> The two zero://*:15441 looks rather like zeronet nodes, at least that's the port zeronet usually uses.

In-network bootstrapping was added some months ago (Bootstrapper plugin), it allows to support Tor nodes + SSL cert pinning (Secure, MITM proof connection).

> Also, the central reliance on ZeroName, along with Namecha.in (which isn't even a part of zeronet!) seems problematic.

The dns resolving are using only the ZeroName site, it does not relies on Namecha.in.

DHT is planned later, but torrent tracker are running since 15year, and probably they will not go anywhere, so it's not a priority yet. You can run your own bootstrapper node on non-internet networks: enable Bootsrapper plugin and add the address to --trackers. (DHT also requires a startup node to work)

To improve privacy ZeroNet creates new Tor hidden service for every site you seeding. It's possible, that Tor guard nodes has same limit on it. Please try if it's working if you seeding smaller number of sites.

To make it work with Tor browser's service then you have to start it using --tor_proxy 127.0.0.1:9150 --tor_controller 127.0.0.1:9151 after you started the browser.

- Tor disabled: You connect only clearnet peers, but if you have opened port Tor peers able to connect to you using exit nodes
- Tor enabled: You connect to clearnet peers directly and Tor peers using Tor, if you don't have opened port other peers able to connect to you using Tor
- Tor only: You connect to clearnet and Tor peers using Tor, other peers only able to connect to you using Tor

1_18ZfPCaU1pYAeos3A7YhZVgtsmXqXeRRW7.body:
- Trackers: Torrent trackers working since 15 years so they probably not going anywhere in the near future. DHT is planned later, but it's not a miracle solution, it also needs a bootstrap node, it adds lots of possible attacks and DHT on TCP is not really works well. (makes Tor clients much less functional)
- Namecoin: Namecoin does not have lightweight resolvers yet (it's [planned](https://www.reddit.com/r/Namecoin/comments/2ug67c/lightweight_resolvers/), but i'm not sure if it's ever finished). Blockstack is still a new technology, not battle tested and the lightweight resolvers are not working yet, but it's looks a good alternative solution in the future. The easiest way to make it less centralized: create more third party zeroname clone sites and if 2 of 3 sites says the same, then it's probably fine.
- ZeroMail: The decryption is done by the site's javascript code, so it's not possible to put messages on newsfeed. Cross-messaging would be nice, but it's not possible until ZeroMail is a simple ZeroNet site. (Probably [merger sites](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/232) will make it possible)
- ZeroId: If you accept all zeroid provider by default then you loose the control over the users, anyone able to create unlimited users (makes impossible to remove misbehaving users).  You can create your own zeroid provider and then the sites able to accept it. Later it could be swiched to blockchain based id, but it would require everyone to own/destroy bitcoins on registration, which is a bad idea at current state of project. (I also dislike this solution, but have not found any better yet)

So thanks for the writing, the concerns are real, but they can be improved later. To solve most of this problems will also mean we need to rely more on third-party networks (Bitcoin, Namecoin, Blockstack), which goes against the "works without internet" purpose of ZeroNet. (and i'm not sure if blockchain based networks will be here in 5 year from now)

> [ks](#comment_63_14TDWFVHuTXNcg8pp6LRr7v9ZcfbFsMSyx): If we use signmessage() / verifymessage() there should be no need to destroy bitcoins (although it will still cost some namepennies to register an ID).

Destroying (or donating) bitcoin is required to have limit on user accounts, without it anyone would able to create many account at low costs.

> [ks](#comment_64_14TDWFVHuTXNcg8pp6LRr7v9ZcfbFsMSyx): Just like any user can create an almost unlimited number of .bit domains, provided they take the trouble and pay for it.

You can, but its not a problem, because you will get no benefits from it. The user creation should cost much more, than domain creation (1000x+)

> [ks](#comment_65_14TDWFVHuTXNcg8pp6LRr7v9ZcfbFsMSyx): Or you could just add another criterion: that a user id should have a certain number of confirmations before it's valid.

It's only delays the user creation, but does not makes it any harder

> [ks](#comment_66_14TDWFVHuTXNcg8pp6LRr7v9ZcfbFsMSyx): And that delay may be all that is needed to give site owners the time to block spamming IDs.
> Plus you could throw in some PoW (e.g., hashcash) if you want to make it harder.

But you can start creating 10000 users at once, so the delay will be ineffective. PoW is not really useful against spam (a powerful GPU able to solve it 1000x faster than an average CPU)

> [p2p](#comment_117_13Z7XxTa7JuFat3KzzMWu3onwM6biLuurJ): is CAPTCHA a good idea?

It's the best that Google found to limit account signups, so probably yes.

> [bukaking](#comment_39_17n5jg4bBEoWodXDf8L4Y2u88ShagS272Y): The obvious problem with sites like ZeroMail is that the owner (or hacker who gets into their computer) can change the code to send data to clearnet server, or create a backdoor to the encrypted message.

There is much simpler solution for that: clone zeromail, symlink data dir to original site's one. This way the site owner does not able to modify the source code anymore, but you get the latest data.

> [bukaking](#comment_40_17n5jg4bBEoWodXDf8L4Y2u88ShagS272Y): It's simple if you know how to symlink on your operating system, if your operating system supports it, which doesn't do much for the general security but rather for whether an individual can and wants to do that, and you could still end up mailing someone or receiving mail from someone who is not as cautious.

If you are going to audit every changes on the source code, then creating a symlink is not a big deal.

> [mmm](#comment_1_18ZfPCaU1pYAeos3A7YhZVgtsmXqXeRRW7): @nofish, your solution is basically: "You just have to archive the source code of the site"

if you dont trust the site owner, then you should create your own copy of the site that can be immutable by simply deleting the private key

> [bukaking](#comment_41_17n5jg4bBEoWodXDf8L4Y2u88ShagS272Y): It doesn't have to be audited by yourself, you could look towards others you trust to audit it, one person could audit code for several people, those people could use their site instead of the default ZeroMail, but they would each have to symlink and know how to symlink have an operating system that allows them to symlink.

One idea: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/414

The other possibility would be the [merger sites](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/232) where the listing/manipulating logic and the data are different sites, so you can clone the listing site and you will still receive the data updates. (but this is not ready yet and will require modification on every sites)

54_1GtJqyJRsuZhmxVtw5USgvqGbUmVH7EmBD.body:
finding file per hash is not possible, because peers groupped by site address and not by content hash.

the easiest way to make it smaller is do not pack more than one site and only include the latest pages and continuously drop the outdated content (eg. older than 1 week)

> [yo](#comment_39_1GtJqyJRsuZhmxVtw5USgvqGbUmVH7EmBD): so we need to re-donwnload zerotalk files(css, js, img) for the english, chinese, spanish, etc  even if those files are already in another local folder ?
> if that is true there is room for optimization

yes (we are talking about ~400kb), if we want to find files by hash then it will need ~5kb/hour network communication for every file + ~50kb memory overhead also per file (to store the peers)
so i highly doubt it would worth it

> [yo](#comment_40_1GtJqyJRsuZhmxVtw5USgvqGbUmVH7EmBD): then how you deal with duplicate files ? (and why should we use zeronet when there is IPFS)

I don't think duplicated files is a real problem. You should use IPFS if you prefer that way.

> [petercxy](#comment_2_1DXR2Di8Ks9JijfNycWErpenoxxchrdWBB): I wonder if it is possible to link to another Zite's resources (all.js etc.) from a Zite. If so, multiple Zites with the same program can share some of their files.

It's disabled, because it would result in more centralization, would add security problems (if site got compromised all of other sites that using the same resource will be also compromised) and there would be no real benefits from it.

> [yo](#comment_43_1GtJqyJRsuZhmxVtw5USgvqGbUmVH7EmBD): defensive much ?

IPFS group peers by content hash, ZeroNet group peers by site owner. You can choose which one is better suited for you.

> [yo](#comment_42_1GtJqyJRsuZhmxVtw5USgvqGbUmVH7EmBD): nah the file or has the hash required or does not have the hash required, there is no way to fake sha512

And then if the other site owner updates the file your site become broken because the missing js file...

> [petercxy](#comment_5_1DXR2Di8Ks9JijfNycWErpenoxxchrdWBB): Maybe a filesystem that supports compression is a good choice for 0net users.

Compressed FS is a good idea, you can also save 50%+ storage space on .json files. Local de-duplication plugin also could be possible. (if you already downloaded the same file from other site don't re-download again, but make a copy/hardlink of it)

> [yo](#comment_44_1GtJqyJRsuZhmxVtw5USgvqGbUmVH7EmBD): have a duplicates folder

6_13hcYDp4XW3GQo4LMtmPf8qUZLZcxFSmVw.body:
It required for two reasons:
 - Ensure no one else has the same username
 - Try to avoid spam. Currently it's easy to register new username, but if its necessary it's possible to create harder id providers: require email verification, fb/google/vk verification, captcha, invite only, reference from other users, etc.

If you don't need these you can easily publish the private key of the cert signer, so anyone able to create new username. (like nanasi do)

Later it's planned to support decentralized, blockchain based identity (namecoin or blockstack).

> [newuser123](#comment_40_1PCPuVtFv8apVpXYbc46wHugNhFUVQ6KCv): What does a hub do?

Storing comments in separate files for every user you have been commented on would result in around 10x of CPU/IO usage (sign/verification/read/write) and around 2 times in hdd usage (per file signature), so its not a good idea. But it's not hard to make a backup script that backups your data and also the users who commented to your posts, then you can move this files to your own hub if necessary.

If you use ZeroNet in Tor always mode, then ZeroNet will use Tor for every connection it make and it's completely hide your IP from every user. If you open a ZeroNet site, then it's browser's responsibility what's going to happen: If your browser sends the internet request started by the javascript source code using the Tor network (like the Tor browser do), then you stay hidden, if it's not, then your real IP address can be shown.

> [kaffie](#comment_209_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): 
> Files are only downloaded from a single peer. They aren't chunked or anything. Different files can come from different peers.

Different files are downloaded from different peers. Giftime has 1000+ files, so it can be downloaded from 1000 different users (workers limited to 20 by default, so it won't). This files are around 1MB so there is no reason to chunk them into more pieces.

> Given 1, your speed displayed would be based on the speed between you and the one peer.

The sidebar downloaded file size are updated every second, so it's not hard to calculate the real bw usage. (or you can use OS's task manager to see the speed)

2_1KWfi9GbSvnLzLM3QbLSBhvRRiB2aq5rjH.body:
- If you want to add new content to someone else's site, then you have to get a digital signature for your username/public address from the certificate provider the site owner defined. This is for make sure noone has the same username as you and also limit user creation.
- Anyone can create a certificate provider and you can also generate it from browser without contacting any central services, but in this case you will lost any control over the users.
- After you got the signature you don't have to contact the id provider again.
- It could be possible to solve it by crypto currencies, but then everyone has to run full node and spend some money on user creation (10USD+ to make it any sense)

> [chiarelli](#comment_6_1Ehiyjqsa14WZrfsmRq54cA1jBXuhcTyjE): I think I understand, because every time a registry is modified / added to the database, the "data.json" file must be signed with the new hash of the "content.json" file, and then be commited in "database.db ". Did I get it right?

> [chiarelli](#comment_7_1Ehiyjqsa14WZrfsmRq54cA1jBXuhcTyjE): Is it mandatory to use "data.json"?

That's the only way to write to the database, you can't use INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE sql commands, only SELECT allowed.

> [chiarelli](#comment_9_1Ehiyjqsa14WZrfsmRq54cA1jBXuhcTyjE): If "database.db" exists what is the need for "data.json"?

The .db files never synced between peers. It's locally generated from .json files, so you don't have to re-download the whole db on every new comment and it's easier to sign/verify per-user content.

I'm not sure if it's a good idea, since it does not support Tor network or ZeroNet configurations, so it could leak your identity. Using a browser [extension](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/torrent-stream/icocmgpofpimcojhefbcfbdldkmndpgj) (or a separate browser that also support Torrent protocol) sounds like a better idea.

2_1PvAednzaMJiuMz1SD5wF3m3Hx7SK75zHv.body:
Method #1: Running 2 clients on different port:
 - Download/unpack Client B to a new directory
 - Start it with `zeronet.py --ui_port 43111 --fileserver_port 15442`
 - Access Client B with https://127.0.0.1:43111

Method #2: Using Multiuser plugin:
 - Rename plugins/disabled-Multiuser to plugins/Multiuser
 - This will enable cookie-based authentication made primary for proxies, start it using `zeronet.py --multiuser_local` if you want to keep settings (eg. newsfeed followings) after restart.
 - In this mode you login/logout to identities on ZeroHello. If you want to be logged in multiple users at the same time, then you need to open different browsers or Client B in private browsing mode, that has separate cookie storage.
